wikipedia_page.main: Joseph Craven (14 December 1825 – 29 November 1914) was a British worsted manufacturer and a Gladstonian Liberal politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1885 to 1892.

response: The Shipley parliamentary constituency was created in 1885, and its first MP was Joseph Craven.

response: *Joseph Craven (Master of Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge) (1661–1728), Master of Sidney Sussex 1723–1728

In 1883 Priestley married Ruth Craven, fourth of the six daughters of Joseph Craven of Thornton, MP for Shipley.Bradford Daily Telegraph, 18 April 1883. Described as her husband’s “alter ego”, she came “from a thoroughbred race of hard-headed people” and was “an ardent Liberal of great intelligence”.Bradford Weekly Telegraph, 18 July 1903.

Gregory was born on 6 October 1887 in Edinburgh, Scotland, the eighth and youngest son of Yorkshire parents. His father, James Gregory, had been a powerful Congregationalist preacher in Leeds before succeeding William Lindsay Alexander at Edinburgh’s Augustine Church (1879) and serving as Chairman of the Congregational Union of Scotland (1890).Congregational Year Book, 1914; The Scotsman, 29 November 1912. His mother, Martha, was a daughter of Joseph Craven, worsted manufacturer and Member of Parliament (MP) for Shipley. The couple returned to Yorkshire in 1896 and James Gregory, having retired from the ministry, was elected a Bradford city councillor and became Chairman of the council’s Higher Education Sub-Committee and President of the local branch of the Workers’ Educational Association. Martha’s brother-in-law, William Priestley, was an MP for the city.Bradford Weekly Telegraph, 29 November 1912; Leeds Times, 30 May 1874; Shipley & Saltaire Times, 21 April 1883; Leeds Mercury, 30 March 1932, 24 August 1935.
